explanation:
OS_FileSys_Initialize — The target calls this symbol; it must be inspected to ensure it is not a macro or inline function that expands into a for statement (or that it does not modify any loop counter or other objects used by a for loop in OS_mkfs). The MISRA rule treats the behavior of called functions as part of a for-loop body, so any loop / side-effects inside this routine could affect compliance.
OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE — Named constant/macro used in the conditional. Verify it is a simple constant (no side-effects, no macro expansion that contains expressions or loops) so it cannot introduce hidden modifications that would violate the for-loop clause restrictions.
OS_ERR_NO_FREE_IDS — Same rationale as above: confirm it is a plain constant/macro without side-effects or embedded code.
OS_FS_ERR_DEVICE_NOT_FREE — Assigned in the function; ensure this macro/constant does not expand to code with side-effects or loops.
int32 — Typedef used as the function return type; include to check whether it is a macro/complex type that could expand to something altering control-flow/introducing loops (rare but must be ruled out for a strict MISRA for-loop analysis).
osal_blockcount_t — Parameter type; include to ensure it is not a macro/complex type with hidden side-effects when used in expressions or macros that could affect loop-counter rules.
size_t — Standard type used in parameters; include to verify it is not redefined as a macro or typedef that could introduce unexpected behaviour.
true — Literal / macro passed as last argument; include to ensure it is the standard boolean literal/macro and not defined in a way that could expand into an expression with side-effects or loops.

Note: The target source contains no for loop itself. The above symbols are the minimal set needed to rule out hidden/macro-expanded for-statements or side-effects originating from called symbols or macros that could cause OS_mkfs to violate the MISRA requirement for well-formed for loops.
